commit_message:
bp/net-debug DRAFT

Change-Id: I1596c7b47eb7e7e6f95b93915ed021ffa753dac2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/qa-specs refs/changes/94/95794/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ============================= Smarter network debuging ============================= ``Attempts to verify guests are running via SSH fails. SSH connection to guest does not work`` style issues can hapen bacuse of 100 ofreasions. Some cases root cause is not even network failure. For example the server does not booted bacuse - A guest timer issue - Volume issue (booting from volume) - or corrupted guest image (swift/glance/download). Many race type issue observed so far related to netwoking including n-net and neutron, which lead to following ending not working conditions: - In-proper int-br vlan tag settings - In-proper dnsmask settings (multiple overlapping or missing entry) - Missing floating IP SNAT/DNAT rules - Accidentally deleted router from the L3 agent - In-proper security group usage - Not started metadata / dnsmask service - ... Using only one bug for all these issues is not useful, the issue needs to be distinguished at least by the ending not working state. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/net-debug Problem description =================== A detailed description of the problem. Proposed change =============== Here is where you cover the change you propose to make in detail. How do you propose to solve this problem? If this is one part of a larger effort make it clear where this piece ends. In other words, what's the scope of this effort? Include where in the tempest tree hierarchy this will reside. If the change is designed to test other OpenStack projects then list which ones it is targeted at. Alternatives ------------ This is an optional section which applies if the blueprint covers infrastructure changes to tempest. For example, blueprints which are just adding more API tests can leave this section empty. Where it does apply we'd just like a demonstration that some thought has been put into why the proposed approach is the best one. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Can optionally can list additional ids if they intend on doing substantial implementation work on this blueprint. Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno-1 Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ - Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in tempest, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. - Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library?

commit_message:
libvirt: speed up get_all_block_devices method

Switch the get_all_block_devices method to use the new
list_instance_domains method.

Blueprint: libvirt-domain-listing-speedup
Change-Id: I8d3fdcbbe5539370583ace6abaffa62fec457d7b

added_lines: def fake_list_all(flags): return [FakeVirtDomain(xml[0], id=3, name="instance00000001"), FakeVirtDomain(xml[1], id=1, name="instance00000002"), FakeVirtDomain(xml[2], id=5, name="instance00000003")] libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listAllDomains = fake_list_all drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) devices = drvr._get_all_block_devices()

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-14 09:12:21.000000000', 'files': ['lib/astute/server/server.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute/commit/18a6861ecf96e20ead17782ef4ea8d62e7449c14', 'message': 'Prevent to requeue main task (run same main task in parallel).

If worker have problem with AMQP connection it can sometimes
do not get acknowledgements for message(main task) instantly
and if worker disconect at this time, message will be requeued

Closes-Bug: #1340704
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent to requeue main task (run same main task in parallel).

If worker have problem with AMQP connection it can sometimes
do not get acknowledgements for message(main task) instantly
and if worker disconect at this time, message will be requeued
and we get several working tasks running in parallel.

Change-Id: If038079e263feb811d019d08944ff1dacd11f30a
Closes-Bug: #1340704
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/14/106714/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @consumer = AMQP::Consumer.new(@channel, @queue, consumer_tag=nil, exclusive=false, no_ack=true)
deleted_lines: @consumer = AMQP::Consumer.new(@channel, @queue) metadata.ack

subject: Allow plugins to choose the EDP implementation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-18 20:42:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara/commit/b5a48f2a90925f0f4f6cfa4388746389fce20b32', 'message': 'Allow plugins to choose the EDP implementation

This change extends the plugin interface and allows plugins
to choose an EDP implementation based on job type and cluster
configuration.

For backwards compatibility, a default implementation
of the method is provided which chooses an EDP implementation based
on job type. Sahara can provide default implementations where it
makes sense, for example the existing Oozie implementation or
a command line implementation for Spark.

Plugins are free to use the default EDP implementations provided,
or they may return any object derived from the JobEngine class.

Partial-implements: blueprint edp-refactor-job-manager
Change-Id: I09d79ac7a3e07d405cd07c4d2d3d283b11fc1baa

commit_message:
Allow plugins to choose the EDP implementation

This change extends the plugin interface and allows plugins
to choose an EDP implementation based on job type and cluster
configuration.

For backwards compatibility, a default implementation
of the method is provided which chooses an EDP implementation based
on job type. Sahara can provide default implementations where it
makes sense, for example the existing Oozie implementation or
a command line implementation for Spark.

Plugins are free to use the default EDP implementations provided,
or they may return any object derived from the JobEngine class.

Partial-implements: blueprint edp-refactor-job-manager
Change-Id: I09d79ac7a3e07d405cd07c4d2d3d283b11fc1baa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/16/101016/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @plugins_base.required_with_default def get_edp_engine(self, cluster, job_type, default_engines): '''Default implementation to select an EDP job engine This method chooses an EDP implementation based on job type. It should be overloaded by a plugin to allow different behavior or the selection of a custom EDP implementation. The default_engines parameter is a list of default EDP implementations. Each item in the list is a dictionary, and each dictionary has the following elements: name (a simple name for the implementation) job_types (a list of EDP job types supported by the implementation) engine (a class derived from sahara.service.edp.base_engine.JobEngine) This method will choose the first engine that it finds which lists the job_type value in the job_types element. An instance of that engine will be allocated and returned. :param cluster: a Sahara cluster object :param job_type: an EDP job type string :param default_engines: a list of dictionaries describing the default implementations. :returns: an instance of a class derived from sahara.service.edp.base_engine.JobEngine or None ''' for eng in default_engines: if job_type in eng["job_types"]: return eng["engine"](cluster)

commit_message:
Document 'POST /v1/.../vendor_passthru'

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/webapi/v1.html does
not contain anything about how to use vendor passthru endpoints.
This adds 'POST /v1/nodes/(node_uuid)/vendor_passthru' and
'POST /v1/drivers/(driver_name)/vendor_passthru' to that
html page.

Change-Id: I6191be759f168c58e80d946530af7a0c4267501c
Closes-Bug: #1331415
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/69/105869/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. rest-controller:: ironic.api.controllers.v1.node:NodeVendorPassthruController :webprefix: /v1/nodes/(node_uuid)/vendor_passthru

commit_message:
Make simple resources to be unbaned everywhere

Change status tio reflect only local
status for both simples and cloned resources
And don't wait for service to start if resource is simple
and it's started elsewhere already but always unban it.

Partial-blueprint: ha-pacemaker-improvements
Closes-Bug: 1340260

Change-Id: I9d7c5079718484c69dee55d3e2a5ead8336eac41
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/10/106110/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if simple? and global_status debug("Not starting to wait for the service to start. Simple resource is started elsewhere.") else debug("Starting countdown for resource start") debug("Start timeout is #{@service[:start_timeout]}") Timeout::timeout(5*@service[:start_timeout],Puppet::Error) do loop do break if status == :running sleep 5 end sleep 3 status = local_status
deleted_lines: debug("Starting countdown for resource start") debug("Start timeout is #{@service[:start_timeout]}") Timeout::timeout(5*@service[:start_timeout],Puppet::Error) do loop do break if status == :running sleep 5 sleep 3 simple = simple? debug "SIMPLE? #{simple}" if simple status = global_status else status = local_status end

commit_message:
Unique_constraint names should be equal for all dialects

Some migrations are not synchronized with models. Models should
provide the same view of database as migrations and vice versa.
In some models  __table_args__ for indexes and unique constraints
is not used.
Unique_constarints should be the same for dialects as it would
be easer to change and drop them in following migration.

Closes-Bug: #1248501

Change-Id: I8cb9ec76d23e3d1cef166d0ebfae698070079312

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # """rename_indexes_lbaas Revision ID: 55480e0f939a Revises: 120ad5f1cf2 Create Date: 2014-03-14 14:46:48.045625 """ # revision identifiers, used by Alembic. revision = '55480e0f939a' down_revision = '120ad5f1cf2' # Change to ['*'] if this migration applies to all plugins migration_for_plugins = [ 'neutron.services.loadbalancer.plugin.LoadBalancerPlugin', ] from alembic import op import sqlalchemy as sa from neutron.db import migration def replace_unique(table, old_name_options, new_name, column): try: op.drop_constraint(old_name_options[1], table, type_='unique') except sa.exc.OperationalError: op.drop_constraint(old_name_options[0], table, type_='unique') op.create_unique_constraint(new_name, table, [column]) def upgrade(active_plugins=None, options=None): if not migration.should_run(active_plugins, migration_for_plugins): return replace_unique('vips', ['pool_id', 'vips_pool_id_key'], 'uniq_vips0pool_id', 'pool_id') replace_unique('providerresourceassociations', ['resource_id', 'providerresourceassociations_resource_id_key'], 'uniq_providerresourceassociations0resource_id', 'resource_id') def downgrade(active_plugins=None, options=None): if not migration.should_run(active_plugins, migration_for_plugins): return op.drop_constraint('uniq_vips0pool_id', 'vips', type_='unique') op.create_unique_constraint('vips_pool_id_key', 'vips', ['pool_id']) op.drop_constraint('uniq_providerresourceassociations0resource_id', 'providerresourceassociations', type_='unique') op.create_unique_constraint('providerresourceassociations_resource_id_key', 'providerresourceassociations', ['resource_id'])

commit_message:
Answer dns record queries

Dns queries for record types are now answered by mdns.  The answers are
obtained from storage and returned.  Currently REFUSED is returned for
SOA.  Once the SOA record type is persisted to storage similar to other
record types, SOA queries would succeed.

Change-Id: I21a766d0564a71b1eb2b7ae0163cb5c786eca48c
Implements: blueprint mdns-designate-mdns-functional

commit_message:
Stop cassandra during configuration and volume migration

The cassandra service is left running after installation.
The next operation(s) are to rewrite the configuration, and
migrate the data onto a volume (if provided). It is not a
good thing for the database to be running during the latter,
and a restart is required after the former.

Failing to stop the database during the data migration can
result in an rsync error 24 because files that were present
when rsync made its list may be missing by the time rsync
gets around to trying to sync that file. This can lead rsync
to not make a 'true' copy of the source on the destination.

The only way around this is to stop the database, something
that is already done by both MongoDB and MySQL in their
guest agents.

Change-Id: I74ecc5c12d43eccc6295488e344bc0e75fe8116d
Closes-bug: #1338660
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/27/106127/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if config_contents or device_path: # while we fix the configuration and the data volume # the database should not be running; install_if_needed() # above will leave the database running. So, stop it. LOG.debug("Stopping database prior to changes.") self.app.stop_db() if config_contents: LOG.debug(_("Processing configuration.")) self.app.write_config(config_contents) self.app.make_host_reachable() if device_path: device = volume.VolumeDevice(device_path) # unmount if device is already mounted device.unmount_device(device_path) device.format() if os.path.exists(mount_point): #rsync exiting data device.migrate_data(mount_point) #mount the volume device.mount(mount_point) LOG.debug("Mounting new volume.") # the database was stopped above. Start it LOG.debug("Restarting database after changes.") self.app.start_db()
deleted_lines: if config_contents: LOG.info(_("Config processing")) self.app.write_config(config_contents) self.app.make_host_reachable() if device_path: device = volume.VolumeDevice(device_path) # unmount if device is already mounted device.unmount_device(device_path) device.format() if os.path.exists(mount_point): #rsync exiting data device.migrate_data(mount_point) #mount the volume device.mount(mount_point) LOG.debug("Mounting new volume.") self.app.restart()

commit_message:
VMware: virt rescue method now supports objects

Commit a37a96fd13b933123e80ad24e37fc37d73c16059 ensured
that the compute API and manager are now getting objects
for the rescue method.

This patch adds support to the virt driver code.

Change-Id: Id7fca437f8470ee483ec3683211766095b293ebf

commit_message:
Update webapi doc with link and console

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/webapi/v1.html is updated
as follows:
- changes the path descriptor of NodeStates to use '(node_uuid)' instead
  of '<uuid>' to be consistent with other paths
- adds [GET/PUT] /v1/nodes/(node_uuid)/states/console to show how to
  access the node's console
- fixes the "Links" section so that Link information is shown

Change-Id: I9d4a32550b81bb5ccf2fa23d8b591d8a945c04cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/02/106102/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Updates Ironic Guide with deployment information

This patch updates
Ironic deployment information
Adds 3 deployment diagrams
Describes deployment process

Change-Id: Idbe973c9a5f9805fe9a186a1db77fc66c044eeaf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/87/100787/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: | | Ironic Deployment Architecture =================================== | We already know that OpenStack services are highly configurable to meet various end-user requirements. The diagrams below are sample deployment scenarios of the Ironic service for bare metal provisioning. | .. figure:: ../images/deployment_architecture_1.png :alt: Deployment Architecture 1 | In the above deployment architecture figure 1.3.1.: | | 1. The controller runs the identity service, management service, dashboard and the management portion of compute. It also contains associated API services, MySQL databases and messaging system. | | 2. The Ironic RESTful api service is used to enroll hardware with attributes like MAC addresses, IPMI credentials etc. A cloud administrator usually enrolls this information for Ironic to manage the specific hardware. | | 3. The compute node runs the Nova compute service, networking plug-in agent and Ironic conductor service. The Ironic conductor service does the bulk of the work. There can be multiple instances of the conductor service to support various class of drivers and also to manage fail over. Ideally, instances of conductor service should be on separate nodes. Each conductor can itself run many drivers to operate heterogeneous hardware. This is depicted in figure 1.3.2. The API exposes a list of supported drivers and the names of conductor hosts servicing them. | .. figure:: ../images/deployment_architecture_2.png :alt: Deployment Architecture 2 | Understanding Bare Metal Deployment ========================================= | What happens when a boot instance request comes in? The below diagram walks through the steps involved during the provisioning of a bare metal instance. | .. figure:: ../images/deployment_steps.png :alt: Deployment Steps | These pre-requisites must be met before the deployment process: | | a. Dependent packages to be configured on the compute node like dnsmasq, tftp-server, ipmi, syslinux etc for bare metal provisioning. | | b. Flavors to be created for the available hardware. Nova must know the flavor to boot from. | | c. Images to be made available in Glance. Different images like deploy kernel and ramdisk images as well as machine images are required for bare metal deployment. | | d. Hardware to be enrolled via Ironic RESTful API service. | Deploy Process ----------------- | 1. Nova boot instance request comes in, messages the API which goes through the message queue | | 2. Nova scheduler applies filter and finds the eligible compute node. | | 3. A spawn task is placed by the driver which contains all information such as which image to boot from etc. It invokes the driver.spawn from the virt layer of Nova compute. | | 4. Information about the bare metal node is retrieved from the bare metal database and the node is reserved. | | 5. Images from Glance are pulled down to the local disks. | | 6. Virtual interfaces are plugged in. | | 7. The bare metal driver deploys the bare metal node which is passed to the Ironic API and the conductor. | | 8. PXE driver prepares tftp bootloader. | | 9. The driver issues IPMI command to enable network boot of a node and power it on. | | 10. The DHCP boots the deploy ramdisk. The PXE driver actually copies the image over iSCSI to the physical node. It connects to the iSCSI end point, partitions volume, "dd" the image and closes the iSCSI connection. The deployment is done. | | 11. The IPMI driver reboots the bare metal node. Note that there are 2 power cycles during bare metal deployment; the first time when powered-on, the images get deployed as mentioned in step 9. The second time as in this case, after the images are deployed, the node is powered up. | | 12. The bare metal node status is updated and the node instance is made available. | |

commit_message:
REST API 'limit' parameter to only accept positive values

The REST API 'limit' parameter was accepting 0 as a valid value, but 0
is not a positive value.

Closes-Bug: #1340280
Change-Id: Ib816c6003da6dee740addb25eb5d4bffe2497967

consistent view when it checks power state from the driver and

commit_message:
synchronize 'stop' and power state periodic task

This change adds the synchronized decorator to the stop function and
_sync_instance_power_state to address a race condition when powering
off and updating the database for an instance. The power off and
database update should be protected so the periodic task sees a
consistent view when it checks power state from the driver and
VM state from the database in order to take action.

In the bug, a stopped instance is in the middle of being rebuilt,
and while it is in the process of being returned to the original
STOPPED state, _sync_power_states sees the combination of the
power state from the driver being 'on' and the vm_state from
the database as being STOPPED. This patch aims to ensure power
'off' and vm_state set to STOPPED happen atomically in the
stop_instance function. Thus, the read by _sync_power_states
must also be synced on the instance UUID.

Change-Id: I8aa83ab8dca35878cf792ae2d46feaa9912ffd38
Closes-Bug: #1320628
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/74/103174/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.synchronized(instance['uuid']) def do_stop_instance(): self._notify_about_instance_usage(context, instance, "power_off.start") self.driver.power_off(instance) current_power_state = self._get_power_state(context, instance) instance.power_state = current_power_state instance.vm_state = vm_states.STOPPED instance.task_state = None instance.save(expected_task_state=task_states.POWERING_OFF) self._notify_about_instance_usage(context, instance, "power_off.end") do_stop_instance() @utils.synchronized(db_instance['uuid']) def get_power_state_and_sync(context, db_instance): pass if db_instance['task_state'] is not None: LOG.info(_("During sync_power_state the instance has a " "pending task (%(task)s). Skip."), {'task': db_instance['task_state']}, instance=db_instance) continue # No pending tasks. Now try to figure out the real vm_power_state. try: get_power_state_and_sync(context, db_instance)
deleted_lines: self._notify_about_instance_usage(context, instance, "power_off.start") self.driver.power_off(instance) current_power_state = self._get_power_state(context, instance) instance.power_state = current_power_state instance.vm_state = vm_states.STOPPED instance.task_state = None instance.save(expected_task_state=task_states.POWERING_OFF) self._notify_about_instance_usage(context, instance, "power_off.end") if db_instance['task_state'] is not None: LOG.info(_("During sync_power_state the instance has a " "pending task (%(task)s). Skip."), {'task': db_instance['task_state']}, instance=db_instance) continue # No pending tasks. Now try to figure out the real vm_power_state. try: continue

commit_message:

commit  569979adfd4237869bb50c7aaa02bc3fd4f0b413
Author: Author: Romain Soufflet <romain@soufflet.io>
Date:   Wed Jul 9 10:45:59 2014 +0200

commit_message:
Fix E251 unexpected spaces around keyword / parameter equals

Pep8 does not like to have linewraps or spaces around kwarg
assignment, so reindent the lines to fulfill the pep8 rules.

Change-Id: I0bcdcd36400e18fb7afa9d07da3f32ba20efa68b

commit_message:
Fix E265 block comment should start with '# '

Address the new pep8 warning that block comments should
start with the sequence '# '.

Change-Id: I52ca5d63b1ca9a465ba36dc9254928f858f2a094

commit_message:
Removed pbr from fuel_agent setup.py

To make it possible to build fuel-agent
package on a system without pbr installed.

Change-Id: I718e1b32c9b5fe840fbaf684f0fdf8df8dce97c2

added_lines: import os import os.path from setuptools import find_packages from setuptools import setup name = 'fuel-agent' version = '0.1.0' def find_requires(): dir_path = os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)) requirements = [] with open('{0}/requirements.txt'.format(dir_path), 'r') as reqs: requirements = reqs.readlines() print requirements return requirements if __name__ == "__main__": setup( name=name, version=version, description='Fuel agent', classifiers=[ 'Development Status :: 4 - Beta', 'Programming Language :: Python' ], author='Mirantis', author_email='fuel-dev@lists.launchpad.net', packages=find_packages(), zip_safe=False, install_requires=find_requires(), entry_points={ 'console_scripts': [ 'agent_new = fuel_agent.cmd.agent:main', 'provision = fuel_agent.cmd.provision:main' ], 'fuel_agent.drivers': [ 'nailgun = fuel_agent.drivers.nailgun:Nailgun' ] } )

commit_message:
Add instance IP to /instances

This new response will be used by Horizon instead of the 1+N calls
Horizon makes today in order to render IPs in the instances list

Change-Id: Ice8f07cdaf873034dc7dc8840fcc403b4756ac12
Closes-Bug: #1339400

commit_message:
Update docstring for api...node.validate

Add the param to the docstring for api.controllers.v1.node.validate.
With this change, the generated webapi page [1] will include this
information. Without it, it shows:
    Validate the driver interfaces. :type node_uuid: uuid

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/webapi/v1.html

Change-Id: Ia33755b7ef1473aa0d04b22c76f20b7f1a99cd6b

commit_message:
VMware: virt unrescue method now supports objects

Commit 65ad230af5ece020822fa963dd30fd641a54ae91 ensured
that the compute API and manager are now getting objects
for the unrescue method.

This patch adds support to the virt driver code.

Change-Id: I42fa532d5b2b1c92121216ac31b56a7b595d59e7

commit_message:
VM diagnostics: add serializer to Diagnostics object

The serializer will enable the API to return a dictionary to the
user.

Part of the blueprint v3-diagnostics

Change-Id: If86a94cba98745acbc9976fa7354c98ec6716ac0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/36/101836/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def serialize(self): s = {} for k, v in self.__dict__.iteritems(): if isinstance(v, list): l = [] for value in v: l.append(value.__dict__) s[k] = l elif isinstance(v, (PrivateDataDiagnostics, MemoryDiagnostics)): s[k] = v.__dict__ else: s[k] = v return s

commit_message:
Use /usr/bin/env python instead of /usr/bin/python

The usage of /usr/bin/env ensures that the first interpreter
found in the environment's $PATH variable is used. This should
be preferred.

Change-Id: I692afbf4ac4ea0c546e4d7480dcf1a7ac158af85

commit_message:
Fix more re-definitions and enable F811/F813 in gate

Additional issues found by flake8 by enabling F811 and
F813. There was only one F813 list comprehension redefinition.
The rest of the changes were F811 redefinition of unused name
violations.

Change-Id: Iad5406c149ab21d360b7e98899a92082197c8c17

commit_message:
Allow usage of several iterators on ModelBase

Storing iterator object as attribute of model doesn't allow
to use several iterators at the same time

Now the new Iterator object which is created by iter()
stores model object, and in such way several iterators can be
created and work without interfering

Change-Id: I5806877a2d15d449b948307a522bf2fb56bf8110

commit_message:
Move the HTML-escaping JavaScript code to a separate function

We might need to use it in more than one place, and it will be easier
to remember about escaping if we have an utility function for that.

Change-Id: I408a1ce055bb2f07b3c146dfa6eb5122fd5434d8

deleted_lines: init_network_list: function() { $(this.get_network_element("")).each(function(){ var name = $this.text().replace(/^\s+/,"") .replace(/&/g, '&') .replace(/</g, '<') .replace(/>/g, '>') .replace(/"/g, '"') .replace(/'/g, ''') .replace(/\//g, '/'); var network_property = { name:name, id:$input.attr("id"), value:$input.attr("value") if($input.is(':checked')) {

subject: Fixed '--version' for trove processes/utilities
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-07 20:28:44.000000000', 'files': ['trove/common/cfg.py', 'trove/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/0bacee9f1a0d4e76ddda6482b7c34c4904883d9a', 'message': "Fixed '--version' for trove processes/utilities

The trove processes (trove-manage, trove-conductor, trove-api, etc.)
returned an empty string when invoked with --version. They now return
the correct version string.

Change-Id: Ic14597e30928c753eae3090b401fbd66e042b93b
Closes-Bug: #1338767
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed '--version' for trove processes/utilities

The trove processes (trove-manage, trove-conductor, trove-api, etc.)
returned an empty string when invoked with --version. They now return
the correct version string.

Change-Id: Ic14597e30928c753eae3090b401fbd66e042b93b
Closes-Bug: #1338767
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/66/105266/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: __all__ = ['__version__'] import pbr.version version_info = pbr.version.VersionInfo('trove') # We have a circular import problem when we first run python setup.py sdist # It's harmless, so deflect it. try: __version__ = version_info.version_string() except AttributeError: __version__ = None

commit_message:
Implement volume type in EC2 API

EC2's volume types: 'standard' and 'io1' are associated with
specific volume types in Cinder via Cinder's volume type
extra-specs. Proper care has been taken so that the existing
deployments won't get affected (where 'standard' volumes were
created with no volume type in Cinder).

Implements-blueprint: ec2-volume-type
Change-Id: I429eadba64dd86628a878cce9f6609ba8b674da1
Closes-Bug: 1259438

commit_message:
VM diagnostics: add methods to class to update diagnotics

Add the following methods:
    - add_cpu
    - add_nic
    - add_disk

The methods will enable the virt driver to update the object.

Change-Id: Id4ca1f188dc955590cd32c634d9c33572f93a5ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/102165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def add_cpu(self, time=0): self.num_cpus += 1 self.cpu_details.append(CpuDiagnostics(time=time)) def add_nic(self, mac_address='00:00:00:00:00:00', rx_octets=0, rx_errors=0, rx_drop=0, rx_packets=0, tx_octets=0, tx_errors=0, tx_drop=0, tx_packets=0): self.num_nics += 1 self.nic_details.append(NicDiagnostics(mac_address=mac_address, rx_octets=rx_octets, rx_errors=rx_errors, rx_drop=rx_drop, rx_packets=rx_packets, tx_octets=tx_octets, tx_errors=tx_errors, tx_drop=tx_drop, tx_packets=tx_packets)) def add_disk(self, id='', read_bytes=0, read_requests=0, write_bytes=0, write_requests=0, errors_count=0): self.num_disks += 1 self.disk_details.append(DiskDiagnostics(id=id, read_bytes=read_bytes, read_requests=read_requests, write_bytes=write_bytes, write_requests=write_requests, errors_count=errors_count))

commit_message:
Fix brocade and embrane plugin migrations

When the auto-generation of db schemas from models is removed [1],
migrations for many plugins breaks. This change fixes migrations
for two plugins:
    brocade
    embrane

Since there are a number of plugins that depend on other plugins, a
dictionary of plugin dependencies is introduced, which is then used
when determining whether migrations should run.

Related-Bug: #1207402 [1]

Closes-Bug: #1298461
Closes-Bug: #1304741

Change-Id: Ia237ce8290b8dd9dd69a989041d80d7c1ef9862b

commit_message:
Sync with oslo-incubator 569979adf

This syncs keystonemiddleware with oslo-incubator commit hash
569979adfd4237869bb50c7aaa02bc3fd4f0b413

First, remove the existing code to cleanup:
    $ rm -r keystonemiddleware/openstack/*

Then, sync from oslo-incubator:
    $ python update.py ../keystonemiddleware

Commits since last sync (55c5629):

3d90045 Backport code for i18n to check lazy at runtime
ef37e03 Added missing jsonutils.dump() function
cb5a804 Move `mask_password` to strutils
de4adbc pep8: fixed multiple violations

Change-Id: If4d060be886ff0c3585b50534d35c87271491b47

subject: Add support for Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI Cinder Driver.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-09 17:50:08.000000000', 'files': ['specs/juno/oracle-zfssa-cinder-driver.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs/commit/3479367228d6f91f89f9ed6d36268d31ff40575c', 'message': 'Add support for Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI Cinder Driver.

Change-Id: Ieb0ef1fe98d9cb406e814b5377d5c7120dcaa5f6
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI Cinder Driver.

Change-Id: Ieb0ef1fe98d9cb406e814b5377d5c7120dcaa5f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/19/105819/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI Driver ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/oracle-zfssa-cinder-driver ZFSSA ISCSI Driver is designed for ZFS Storage Appliance product line (ZS3-2, ZS3-4, ZS3-ES, 7420 and 7320). The driver provides the ability to create iSCSI volumes which are exposed from the ZFS Storage Appliance for use by VM instantiated by Openstack's Nova module. Problem description =================== Currently there is no support for ZFS Storage Appliance product line from Openstack Cinder. Proposed change =============== iSCSI driver uses REST API to communicate out of band with the storage controller. The new driver would be located under cinder/volume/drivers/zfssa, and it would be able to perform the following: * Create/Delete Volume * Extend Volume * Create/Delete Snaphost * Create Volume from Snapshot * Delete Volume Snapshot * Attach/Detach Volume * Get Volume Stats Additionaly a ZFS Storage Appliance workflow (cinder.akwf) is provided to help the admin to setup a user and role in the appliance with enought priviledges to do cinder operations. Also, cinder.conf has to be configured properly with zfssa specific properties for the driver to work. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- User will be able to use ZFS Storage Appliance product line with Openstack Cinder. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: juan-c-zuluaga <juan.c.zuluaga@oracle.com> Other contributors: brian-ruff <brian.ruff@oracle.com> Work Items ---------- All the features that ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI does. Add CI unit test for ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI Cinder Driver Dependencies ============ Minimum ZFS Storage Appliance with OS8.2 Testing ======= CI will be performed for ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI Driver. Documentation Impact ==================== Cinder Support Matrix should be updated. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CinderSupportMatrix References ========== http://www.oracle.com/us/products/servers-storage/storage/nas/overview/index.html **ZFS Storage Appliance Workflow.** http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E26765_01/html/E26397/maintenance__workflows.html#maintenance__workflows__bui

commit_message:
libvirt: speed up list_instances method

Switch the list_instances method to use the new
list_instance_domains method. This removes the last
user of list_instance_ids, so delete that method.

Blueprint: libvirt-domain-listing-speedup
Change-Id: I101c42799589f01a830d974e48a1fd4b9fc60371
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/23/105123/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: vm1 = FakeVirtDomain(id=3, name="instance00000001") vm2 = FakeVirtDomain(id=17, name="instance00000002") vm3 = FakeVirtDomain(name="instance00000003") vm4 = FakeVirtDomain(name="instance00000004") def fake_list_all(flags): vms = [] if flags & libvirt.VIR_CONNECT_LIST_DOMAINS_ACTIVE: vms.extend([vm1, vm2]) if flags & libvirt.VIR_CONNECT_LIST_DOMAINS_INACTIVE: vms.extend([vm3, vm4]) return vms libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listAllDomains = fake_list_all drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) names = drvr.list_instances() self.assertEqual(names[0], vm1.name()) self.assertEqual(names[1], vm2.name()) self.assertEqual(names[2], vm3.name()) self.assertEqual(names[3], vm4.name())
deleted_lines: libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.lookupByID = self.fake_lookup libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.numOfDomains = lambda: 2 libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDomainsID = lambda: [0, 1] libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDefinedDomains = lambda: [] conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) instances = conn.list_instances() # Only one should be listed, since domain with ID 0 must be skipped self.assertEqual(len(instances), 1) def test_list_defined_instances(self): self.mox.StubOutWithMock(libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver, '_conn') libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.lookupByID = self.fake_lookup libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.numOfDomains = lambda: 1 libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDomainsID = lambda: [0] libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDefinedDomains = lambda: [1] self.mox.ReplayAll() conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) instances = conn.list_instances() # Only one defined domain should be listed self.assertEqual(len(instances), 1) def test_list_instances_when_instance_deleted(self): def fake_lookup(instance_name): raise libvirt.libvirtError("we deleted an instance!") self.mox.StubOutWithMock(libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver, '_conn') libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.lookupByID = fake_lookup libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.numOfDomains = lambda: 1 libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDomainsID = lambda: [0, 1] libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDefinedDomains = lambda: [] self.mox.StubOutWithMock(libvirt.libvirtError, "get_error_code") libvirt.libvirtError.get_error_code().AndReturn( libvirt.VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN) self.mox.ReplayAll() conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) instances = conn.list_instances() # None should be listed, since we fake deleted the last one self.assertEqual(len(instances), 0) def test_list_instances_throws_nova_exception(self): def fake_lookup(instance_name): raise libvirt.libvirtError("we deleted an instance!") self.mox.StubOutWithMock(libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver, '_conn') libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.lookupByID = fake_lookup libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.numOfDomains = lambda: 1 libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDomainsID = lambda: [0, 1] libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver._conn.listDefinedDomains = lambda: [] self.mox.StubOutWithMock(libvirt.libvirtError, "get_error_code") libvirt.libvirtError.get_error_code().AndReturn( libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR) self.mox.ReplayAll() conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) self.assertRaises(exception.NovaException, conn.list_instances)

commit_message:
Imporve read me

*) Change version from 0.2.4 to 0.2.5
*) Integration with oslo.messaging is going to be done in different way
*) Change default points for trace - and add reason why they are important

Change-Id: I38541034ad9318cca925bd7fc931d24f9b86b51a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler refs/changes/63/106663/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OSprofiler API version 0.2.5 * Add `OSprofiler WSGI middleware`_ to service, that initialize profiler, if there are special trace headers, that are singed by HMAC from api-paste.ini It's well known that projects are using `oslo.messaging`_ to deal with RPC. It's very good, cause projects deal with RPC in similar way. So there are 2 required changes: * On callee side put in Context object trace info (if profiler is initialized) * On caller side if there is trace info in Context initialize profiler. * Trace all methods of caller API (can be done via profiler.trace_cls). message. I think that for all projects we should include by default 5 kinds of points: * All HTTP calls - helps to get information about: what HTTP requests were done, duration of calls (latency of service), information about projects involved in request. * All RPC calls - helps to understand duration of parts of request related to different services in one project. This information is essential to understand which service produce the bottleneck. * All DB API calls - in some cases slow DB query can produce bottleneck. So it's quite useful to track how much time request spend in DB layer. * All driver calls - in case of nova, cinder and others we have vendor drivers. Duration * ALL SQL requests (turned off by default, because it produce a lot of traffic).. _OSprofiler WSGI middleware: https://github.com/stackforge/osprofiler/blob/master/osprofiler/web.py
deleted_lines: OSprofiler API version 0.2.0 * Add OSprofiler WSGI middleware to service, that will init profiler, if there are special trace headers. It's well known that projects are using oslo.messaging to deal with RPC. So the best way to enable cross service tracing (inside of project) is to add trace info to all messages (in case of inited profiler). And initialize profiler on callee side, if there is trace info in the message. I think that for all projects we should include by default 3 kinds of points: * All HTTP calls * All RPC calls * All DB calls

update allowedaddress pair correctly

Besides adding or removing allowed address pairs,
this patch enables clearing the allowed address pairs.

added_lines: from neutron.extensions import allowedaddresspairs as addr_pair def test_update_add_address_pairs(self): with self.port() as port: address_pairs = [{'mac_address': '00:00:00:00:00:01', 'ip_address': '10.0.0.1'}] update_port = {'port': {addr_pair.ADDRESS_PAIRS: address_pairs}} req = self.new_update_request('ports', update_port, port['port']['id']) port = self.deserialize(self.fmt, req.get_response(self.api)) # NOTE(gongysh) the return port returned by # update is not accurate body = self._show('ports', port['port']['id']) self.assertEqual(body['port'][addr_pair.ADDRESS_PAIRS], address_pairs)

commit_message:
Shift sysctl.d writing code to a new script

sysctl-set-value also sets the value on the build system, which
may cause unintended side effects while building images on
machines. Since most of these side effects are harmless, most
call sites can continue to use it, but also allow elements to
set a sysctl value that does not take immediate effect on the
host by just writing the file.

Change-Id: Ife8a156a22a305603c6b0af1c095e073e492a4b9

commit_message:
Arista L3 Router Service Plugin

New L3 Router serice plugin to support hardware based routing on Arista
hardware.

Change-Id: I1eb5452947dd46b88329e218b50d3169b2645711
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/25/97125/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================================================================== Layer 3 service plugin to support hardware based routing on Arista devices ========================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/arista-l3-service-plugin This blueprint is to implement a L3 service plugin to support hardware based Layer 3 routing in Arista devices. Problem description =================== This service plugin implements neutron L3 routing features on Arista hardware. It communicates with Arista hardware fabric over JSON RPC to automate the provisioning of routing on Arista devices (both at leaf and spine layer). Proposed change =============== This proposal is to introduce a new Layer 3 service plugin that uses JSON RPC to to communicate with Arista hardware fabric to provide following routing functions: * Create a router * Update a router * Delete a router * Add a new router interface * Delete a router interface Initial version of this plugin will implement only routing functions. In future it will be enhanced to support additional neutron L3 functions. This plugin works in conjuction with Arista ML2 Driver, which manages the networks, subnets, and ports. This service plugin and ML2 Driver leverage the resources and topology knowledge to facilitate the automation of L2 and L3 provisioning in Arista hardware. Alternatives ------------ The alternative approach is to use the open source agent based layer 3 router plugin which is not best suited for Arista hardware. Data model impact ----------------- n.a. REST API impact --------------- n.a Security impact --------------- n.a Notifications impact -------------------- n.a. Other end user impact --------------------- n.a. Performance Impact ------------------ This service plugin is event based triggered. No polling is deployed. There are no changes to any existing code patterns. This plugin uses JSON RPC to communicate with Arista hardware. Arista ML2 Driver uses the same mechanism and implements bulk operations to support scale deployements. This plugin will leverage the same mechanisms. Other deployer impact --------------------- Configuration knobs will be provided to the adminstrators to take advantage of various deployment topologies supported by Arista fabric. These configuration knobs will be documented on OpenStack wiki. Developer impact ---------------- n.a. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Sukhdev Kapur sukhdev@arista.com IRC - Sukhdev Work Items ---------- * L3 Service Plugin * DevStack related enhancements to support this plugin Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Complete unit test coverage of the code will be provided. For full tempest test coverage, Arista third party testing is implemented and is described at the following wiki. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Arista-third-party-testing Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation to configure and deploy this service plugin will be provided in the Openstack wiki. References ========== TBD

commit_message:
network allocation retry logic update

while network allocation is being retried,
the retry logic is improved to avoid the
retry_time calculation once retry_time
reaches beyond 30 seconds.

Change-Id: I449fbf7e3fd8a905273731e84587da15e792d13e
Closes-bug: #1334233

commit_message:
Adding the data_image_registry panel for Sahara

The data_image_registry panel allows for tagging
images with the flavors and versions of hadoop that they
support.  Those tags are used in creating clusters to
be sure that a cluster has all the necessary pieces to
function properly.
This code was originally from:
https://github.com/openstack/sahara-dashboard

Change-Id: I647c03a0ce9b802dd1100bce49dc46e24cac7190
Partial-Implements: blueprint merge-sahara-dashboard
Co-Authored-By: Nikita Konovalov <nkonovalov@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Mescheryakov <dmescheryakov@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Add hacking check for log translation domains

As there are many patches have done changes about the log translation
domain check. This patch provide a hacking check rule about log translation
domain. This hacking rule is disable now, after all the codes of Nova
being changed to conform to the log translation domain rule, this hacking
check will need to be enable.

Change-Id: I645aa3ac50691010abab478020296f83af17561b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/61/105661/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_log_translation_domains(self): log_domains = {'info': '_LI', 'warn': '_LW', 'warning': '_LW', 'error': '_LE', 'critical': '_LC'} for k, v in log_domains.items(): log = 'LOG.%(level)s(%(domain)s("test_log"))' % {'level': k, 'domain': v} log_noqa = log + ' # noqa' log_no_domain = 'LOG.%(level)s(%(domain)s("test_log"))' % { 'level': k, 'domain': '_'} self.assertEqual(0, len(list( checks.log_translation_domains(log, log, 'f')))) self.assertEqual(0, len(list( checks.log_translation_domains(log, log_noqa, 'f')))) self.assertEqual(1, len(list( checks.log_translation_domains(log_no_domain, log_no_domain, 'f'))))

commit_message:
Convert base HTTP tests to httpretty

Instead of mocking the requests library we use HTTPretty which allows us
to mock the interaction at the socket layer. This is much less brittle
to argument changes than mocking requests directly.

Change-Id: Ic26b241d2e39b65dee650fbfa2763003b2fdedb3
blueprint: httpretty-testing

commit_message:
Fix wrong json response body for paginated collections

In "Example 1.4. Tenant collection, first page: JSON response", the
content is actually XML and not JSON.

Change-Id: Ie0db0b9a01418171c12856f49a6967c2adf5b207
Closes-Bug: #1338111

commit_message:
Fix issue with trace_cls

If we add to class attribute that is callable, trace_cls will
try to wrap it => create a lot of pain.

So trace only functions and methods

Change-Id: If34223fa7a77667f5a0875f7a7b3b4e227ef1083
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler refs/changes/60/106660/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not (inspect.ismethod(attr) or inspect.isfunction(attr)): continue if attr_name.startswith("__"):
deleted_lines: if not callable(attr) or attr_name.startswith("__"):

commit_message:
Two messages in exceptions.py not setup for localization

These two messages in exceptions.py are
not setup for localization and so I have fixed them.

Closes-bug: #1332310
Change-Id: I43895824d405ceae06ba0bc89164b786f112cd50

subject: Stage logs and artifacts
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-24 21:35:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/solum-specs/commit/e2a88b29de5ac637e8276b5eece493f2f4dcb897', 'message': 'Stage logs and artifacts

Solum needs to collect the output artifacts of each stage of assembly creation,

commit_message:
Stage logs and artifacts

Solum needs to collect the output artifacts of each stage of assembly creation,
and associate those artifacts with the assemblies for reference and debugging
by users of Solum.

Change-Id: I64de1407dfa2f6d137adf4c502a166fa6255af59
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum-specs refs/changes/56/102356/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Stage logs and artifacts ======================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/solum/+spec/stage-logs Solum needs to collect the output artifacts of each stage of assembly creation, and associate those artifacts with the assemblies for reference and debugging by users of Solum. Problem description =================== At present, users of Solum have no insight as to the cause of their failed builds short of the "status" field of their assembly. Moreover, the logs for each popen("docker run build-app") and similar calls are appended raw into the worker logs, which means not only can a user not see the logs, but admins of Solum have no choice but to see such logs interspersed with the information they'd actually need to see. Besides that, in the case of multiple workers, it is likely that the output of several agents at once could interlace their output, making it even more difficult to retrieve and parse the logs. Proposed change =============== I propose the following changes: * Configure a root-level logging directory, SOLUM_STAGE_LOG_DIR - example: "/var/log/solum/" * For each agent (deployer, worker, so forth), a logfile in SOLUM_STAGE_LOG_DIR - example: "worker.log" * As a single unit-test or build-app task is executed, capture the output of the "docker run" command, and log it to the appropriate file as a JSON blob: { "@timestamp": "<iso8601 timestamp>", "tenant_id": "<tenant id>", "assembly_id": "<assembly id>", "solum_stage": "<'unittest', 'build-app', etc>", ... "message": "<captured output>" } and any other relevant data we may deem necessary. This format is suggested as a simple way for this logging mechanism to interface with log-consuming tools like Logstash or ElasticSearch, or even just syslog. This approach is not only applicable to the unittest stage, but also to the other stages. There is currently a bug that build-app's output is not available to users; this proposal can be applied to solve that problem, too. Alternatives ------------ We can also use Swift to store the documents, but there are several complications, the first of which is simply that Swift is not already a dependency of Solum. While that may not always be the case, I think we ought to offer at least a minimum solution and perhaps later build a configurable interface for deployers of Solum to decide upon themselves. Data model impact ----------------- Depending on the format and contents of other artifacts that are not logs, it may be useful if not plainly necessary for us to associate artifacts to their assemblies either by adding a field or fields to the Assembly table, or by creating a new Artifacts table, whose schema would include at miniumum: - artifact_id - tenant_id - assembly_id - created_at - location (glance url, swift url, local fs path, etc) REST API impact --------------- The REST API will be affected only minimally. The results of "assembly show" may end up bearing additional fields to point to its artifacts, as mentioned above. Security impact --------------- Exposing the output of a docker container running user unit tests against user code is no more dangerous than running those tests against the code is originally. One concern of this format is making sure only the owner of an assembly can retrieve its artifacts. The concern of a user filling up storage is not a large concern. Ideally, system monitor triggers ought to warn long before a user exhausts all available storage with a single docker container. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Notifications impact -------------------- I don't think any notifications will be impacted by this change. Other end user impact --------------------- A deployer of Solum could likely employ a log consumption tool like Logstash to present the logs to a user. I do not propose any way to expose artifacts directly to users via the API. Performance Impact ------------------ I do not foresee any large impact, positive or negative, on performance. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers of Solum will likely find they'll need to employ logrotate in the directory holding the artifacts. Developer impact ---------------- Future developers will be able to reuse this setup for future stages-- functional testing, for example. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Ed Cranford (ed--cranford) will implement this logging proposal. Work Items ---------- * Add configurable path and ensure the directory is created as worker starts. * Modify unittest worker task to capture output of docker run and append to appropriate logfile. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= This is a practical change, and difficult to test automatically. This is further complicated by the differences between the development environment VM and an actual deployed Solum environment, which may be distributed across several distinct hosts and present accessibilty problems we cannot foresee in development. Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation changes must cover minimally: - For operators, how to configure the logging location. - For users, how to retrieve the output of assembly stages. References ========== None

commit_message:
Make oslotest independent form mox

We should try to reduce usage of mox in all OpenStack projects,
cause mock is better library. So it makes sense to not add hidden
dependencies to mox via usage of oslotest.

If project would like to use mox, it'll need to add in test-requirments
mox.

Change-Id: I7de0d56cc10e1c58ff601f4e9f467a1b70a27e70
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslotest refs/changes/06/103406/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Enable cross service profiling

This patch is essential, it adds support to bind trace between
services of one project (when they are using rpc calls).

So the idea is quite simple, synchronize 2 instance of profilers
in 2 services.

So if profiler is initialized (on caller service) it will pass extra key in
message with trace info. On consumer side if there is trace info in message we
are initializing profiler with trace info. This allows us to have 1 trace that
will go through all services.

As well we are sending notification for all rpc calls. Using
profiler.start() and profiler.stop(). But no worries there is no impact on
performance in case of not initialized profiler.

Implements bp: enable-cross-service-profiling

Change-Id: Ie7cf688f6f0a88095622c31f54fcb9179544bd99
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/71/103271/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from osprofiler import profiler trace_info = message.pop('trace_info', None) if trace_info: profiler.init(**trace_info) profiler.start('rpc', info={ 'rpc.target': str(target), 'rpc.method': str(method), 'rpc.args': str(args) }) profiler.stop()

commit_message:
Add blueprint for support-volume-num-weighter

Add a volume number weighter to help improve volume-backends'
IO balance and volumes' IO performance.

blueprint support-volume-num-weighter

Change-Id: I3d7e1315c1601b280a5a35d8c0c1f3736631b26c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/83/99683/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Support Volume Num Weighter =========================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/support-volume-num-weighter Provide a mean to help improve volume-backends' IO balance and volumes' IO performance. Problem description =================== Currently cinder support choosing volume backend according to free_capacity and allocated_capacity. Volume Num Weighter is that scheduler could choose volume backend based on volume number in volume backend, which could provide another mean to help improve volume-backends' IO balance and volumes' IO performance. Explain the benifit from volume number weighter by this use case. Assume we have volume-backend-A with 300G and volume-backend-B with 100G. Volume-backend-A's IO capabilities is the same volume-backend-B IO capabilities. Each volume's IO usage are almost the same. Use CapacityWeigher as weighter class. Concrete Use Case: If we create six 10G volumes, these volumes would placed in volume-backend A. All the six volume IO stream has been push on volume-backend-A, which would cause volume-backend-A does much IO scheduling work. At the same time, volume-backend-B has no volume and its IO capabilites has been wasted. If we have volume number weighter, scheduler could do proper initial placement for these volumes----three on volume-backend A, three on volume-backend-B. So that we can make full use of all volume-backends' IO capabilities to help improve volume-backends' IO balance and volumes' IO performance. Proposed change =============== Add a volume number weighter. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ling-yun Work Items ---------- * Implement Volume Number Weighter Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== The cinder configuration documentation will need to be updated to reflect the weighter changes. References ========== None

Display volume size for trove instances

Add volume size (in GB) to the trove databases
table and the database details page

commit_message:
Rename Trove panels to remove redundant information

Currently all Trove panels in the navigation panel
are prepended with the word 'Database' - this is
redundant and wasteful of space as we get more /
longer panel names

Remove the word 'Database' from panel names in
the navigation panel

Change-Id: I481178c0aa1d99b2c775750a1f66fd2aa51e8647
Closes-Bug: #1336490

commit_message:
Load the maximum console bytes from instance metadata

With this change, users can set the maximum console output bytes in
the instance metadata. It's useful for users who want to get more
than 10KB console log which is currently set as default.

Change-Id: Ife4800458b5bdc3ebcf944c10c4d0fef48e9c280
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/105988/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: max_console_bytes = MAX_CONSOLE_BYTES if instance["metadata"]["max_console_bytes"]: max_console_bytes = instance["metadata"]["max_console_bytes"] * units.Ki max_console_bytes) log_data, remaining = utils.last_bytes(fp, max_console_bytes)
deleted_lines: MAX_CONSOLE_BYTES) log_data, remaining = utils.last_bytes(fp, MAX_CONSOLE_BYTES)

commit_message:
Clean up base Volume Driver

This is a preliminary cleanup of the base
Volume Driver to prepare for adding new
architecture which keeps the Control calls
and connection portions of the drivers
seperated from each other.

This doesn't break existing compatability or drivers
but just makes some of the necessary tweaks and additions
to enable implementation of decoupled Control and Data
sides of the Volume drivers.

POC for this proposal is here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/104701/

FYI check-up2-date is going to be the death of us all!

Change-Id: Ifc844c49ee9ff1580d5da0879e7d499bed72dac1

commit_message:
Fix inconsistencies in service restart

Make the neutron-server restart more consistent in the cloud admin
guide.

Add a step to restart the DHCP agent after a change in its
configuration.

Fix identation of the NSX sample.

Change-Id: I3eaa5a13f12c6c8133f8e43d87aeb8d99169cf4f
Closes-Bug: #1328741

commit_message:
Re-mount swift disk image in start-deps

In redstack start-deps ensure that the swift disk image is mounted,
e.g. after a reboot.

Closes-Bug: 1334431
Change-Id: Ic2004f62d59c4e1c9c64f44e2b6eeed1f4f1dcb9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/42/102642/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ! egrep -q ${SWIFT_DATA_DIR}/drives/sdb1 /proc/mounts; then exclaim "Re-mounting Swift Disk Image" sudo mount -t xfs -o loop,noatime,nodiratime,nobarrier,logbufs=8 ${SWIFT_DISK_IMAGE} ${SWIFT_DATA_DIR}/drives/sdb1 fi

An empty choiceField now says

commit_message:
Consistent handling of choiceField for backups

CHanged the way we initially populate the restore
backups choice field in the trove launch dialog
so that it is consistent with other choice fields
in horizon dashboard e.g. compute->instances

An empty choiceField now says
'No backups available'
and a populated choiceFIeld will have an initial
selection of
'Select backup'

Change-Id: I1b0f57656bd649ad92268789f35c9ba77223dbc9
Closes-bug: #1340867
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/52/106452/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: choices = [(b.id, b.name) for b in backups if b.status == 'COMPLETED' ] except Exception: choices = [] if choices: choices.insert(0, ("", _("Select backup"))) else: choices.insert(0, ("", _("No backups available"))) return choices
deleted_lines: empty = [('', '-')] backup_list = [(b.id, b.name) for b in backups if b.status == 'COMPLETED'] except Exception: backup_list = [] return empty + backup_list

commit_message:
Add pre-install phase for extras.d plugins

An additional call hook for the extras.d plugins that is called before
any service installation occurs turns out to be needed by Ceph and
useful for other plugins.

This is called between the installation of the system packages listed
as prerequisites and the installation of the actual services.

Change-Id: Id723bdc7542182d2b2eff40c0dc0127307f094c5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/89/105789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Extras Pre-install # ------------------ # Phase: pre-install if [[ -d $TOP_DIR/extras.d ]]; then for i in $TOP_DIR/extras.d/*.sh; do [[ -r $i ]] && source $i stack pre-install done fi

commit_message:
Add @profiler.trace_cls decorator

* This decorator allows us to add @trace to all public (and optionally
private) methods of class.

Sample of usage

> @profiler.trace_cls("rpc", info={"any": "info"}, hide_args=False, trace_private=False)
> class SomeClass(object):
>
>     def traced_method(self, arg1, arg2):
>         pass
>
>     def _non_traced_method(self, some_arg)
>         pass

* Improved @profiler.trace decorator
  Now it set's full path path including class name of method.

* Use separated scope for method's: name, args, kwargs.
  make it much easier to read trace info

* Update read me

Change-Id: I45b0dd7c2acdfc5bf66470bd4d15872a3a379af5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler refs/changes/81/106581/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch("osprofiler.profiler.stop") @mock.patch("osprofiler.profiler.start") def test_decorator_trace_cls(self, mock_start, mock_stop): @profiler.trace_cls("rpc", info={"a": 10}) class FakeTracedCls1(object): def method1(self, a, b, c=10): return a + b + c def method2(self, d, e): return d - e def method3(self, g=10, h=20): return g * h def _method(self, i): return i fake_cls = FakeTracedCls1() self.assertEqual(30, fake_cls.method1(5, 15)) expected_info = { "a": 10, "method": "tests.test_profiler.FakeTracedCls1.method1", "args": str((fake_cls, 5, 15)), "kwargs": str({}) } mock_start.assert_called_once_with("rpc", info=expected_info) mock_stop.assert_called_once_with() mock_start.reset_mock() mock_stop.reset_mock() self.assertEqual(50, fake_cls.method3(g=5, h=10)) expected_info = { "a": 10, "method": "tests.test_profiler.FakeTracedCls1.method3", "args": str((fake_cls,)), "kwargs": str({"g": 5, "h": 10}) } mock_start.assert_called_once_with("rpc", info=expected_info) mock_stop.assert_called_once_with() mock_start.reset_mock() mock_stop.reset_mock() self.assertEqual(10, fake_cls._method(10)) self.assertFalse(mock_start.called) self.assertFalse(mock_stop.called) @mock.patch("osprofiler.profiler.stop") @mock.patch("osprofiler.profiler.start") def test_decorator_trace_cls_without_args(self, mock_start, mock_stop): @profiler.trace_cls("rpc", info={"b": 20}, hide_args=True) class FakeTracedCls2(object): def method1(self, a, b, c=10): return a + b + c fake_cls = FakeTracedCls2() self.assertEqual(40, fake_cls.method1(5, 15, c=20)) expected_info = { "b": 20, "method": "tests.test_profiler.FakeTracedCls2.method1", } mock_start.assert_called_once_with("rpc", info=expected_info) mock_stop.assert_called_once_with() @mock.patch("osprofiler.profiler.stop") @mock.patch("osprofiler.profiler.start") def test_decorator_trace_cls_private_methods(self, mock_start, mock_stop): @profiler.trace_cls("rpc", trace_private=True) class FakeTracedCls3(object): def _method1(self, a, b): return a * b fake_cls = FakeTracedCls3() self.assertEqual(75, fake_cls._method1(5, 15)) expected_info = { "method": "tests.test_profiler.FakeTracedCls3._method1", "args": str((fake_cls, 5, 15)), "kwargs": str({}) } mock_start.assert_called_once_with("rpc", info=expected_info) mock_stop.assert_called_once_with()

which Sahara throws right after you start an EDP job

Closes-Bug: #1339743

commit_message:
Fix continuous test failure with latest pecan

The test_list_resources_by_unknown_field testcase is failing with the
new pecan version (0.6.0) with the NullIndexer. With PostgreSQL
all the list_resources related tests are failing.

After creating a resource, as a first step, in the
test_list_resources_by_unknown_field testcase it starts working, the
test skipping logic is not failing because of getting the standard
HTTP Resource Not Found error coming from webob instead of the
NotImplemented error.

Change-Id: If9d536a4060624a3baf37e082e397bb8afccb6fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/66/104966/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_get_non_existing_resource(self): result = self.app.get("/v1/resource/" + self.resource_type + "/" + self.attributes['id'], expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(400, result.status_code) self.app.post_json( "/v1/resource/" + self.resource_type, params=self.attributes)

commit_message:
Clean up nova virt driver test code

Some minor cleanup of the nova.virt.ironic driver test code.

Change-Id: If9e21cc9dc521b65561fdc96c5c5591abc03f72e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/25/105925/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.openstack.common import jsonutilsdef _get_properties(): return {'cpus': 2, 'memory_mb': 512, 'local_gb': 10, 'cpu_arch': 'x86_64'} def _get_stats(): return {'cpu_arch': 'x86_64', 'capabilities': 'None', 'ironic_driver': 'ironic.nova.virt.ironic.driver.IronicDriver', 'test_spec': 'test_value'} node_uuid = uuidutils.generate_uuid() instance_uuid = uuidutils.generate_uuid() props = _get_properties() stats = _get_stats() instance_uuid=instance_uuid, properties=props) self.assertEqual(props['cpus'], result['vcpus']) self.assertEqual(props['cpus'], result['vcpus_used']) self.assertEqual(props['memory_mb'], result['memory_mb']) self.assertEqual(props['memory_mb'], result['memory_mb_used']) self.assertEqual(props['local_gb'], result['local_gb']) self.assertEqual(props['local_gb'], result['local_gb_used']) self.assertEqual(stats, jsonutils.loads(result['stats'])) node_uuid = uuidutils.generate_uuid() props = _get_properties() stats = _get_stats() properties=props) self.assertEqual(props['cpus'], result['vcpus']) self.assertEqual(props['memory_mb'], result['memory_mb']) self.assertEqual(props['local_gb'], result['local_gb']) self.assertEqual(stats, jsonutils.loads(result['stats'])) node_uuid = uuidutils.generate_uuid() props = _get_properties() stats = _get_stats() properties=props) self.assertEqual(stats, jsonutils.loads(result['stats']))

commit_message:
Update requirements to oslo.config>=1.4.0.0a1

oslo.config 1.4.0.0a1 added the config fixture which Keystone can use
so that it doesn't have to use the one in oslo-incubator.

Change-Id: I72dc87591df8da260f689e38bee999cd25bbd48f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/53/103253/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: oslo.config>=1.2.1

commit_message:
Minor fixes to examples

* Fix typo in authenticate
* Add comments to head command
* Fix name of head method
* Use find_resource_cls for lists

commit_message:
Update oslo-incubator strutils module

Changes -
 * Move `mask_password` to strutils

Change-Id: I6d0f367761241bfe0ae2242de2436e62b40e643e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-saharaclient refs/changes/42/106242/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(flaper87): The following 3 globals are used by `mask_password` _SANITIZE_KEYS = ['adminPass', 'admin_pass', 'password', 'admin_password'] # NOTE(ldbragst): Let's build a list of regex objects using the list of # _SANITIZE_KEYS we already have. This way, we only have to add the new key # to the list of _SANITIZE_KEYS and we can generate regular expressions # for XML and JSON automatically. _SANITIZE_PATTERNS = [] _FORMAT_PATTERNS = [r'(%(key)s\s*[=]\s*[\"\']).*?([\"\'])', r'(<%(key)s>).*?(</%(key)s>)', r'([\"\']%(key)s[\"\']\s*:\s*[\"\']).*?([\"\'])', r'([\'"].*?%(key)s[\'"]\s*:\s*u?[\'"]).*?([\'"])', r'([\'"].*?%(key)s[\'"]\s*,\s*\'--?[A-z]+\'\s*,\s*u?[\'"])' '.*?([\'"])', r'(%(key)s\s*--?[A-z]+\s*)\S+(\s*)'] for key in _SANITIZE_KEYS: for pattern in _FORMAT_PATTERNS: reg_ex = re.compile(pattern % {'key': key}, re.DOTALL) _SANITIZE_PATTERNS.append(reg_ex) def mask_password(message, secret="***"): """Replace password with 'secret' in message. :param message: The string which includes security information. :param secret: value with which to replace passwords. :returns: The unicode value of message with the password fields masked. For example: >>> mask_password("'adminPass' : 'aaaaa'") "'adminPass' : '***'" >>> mask_password("'admin_pass' : 'aaaaa'") "'admin_pass' : '***'" >>> mask_password('"password" : "aaaaa"') '"password" : "***"' >>> mask_password("'original_password' : 'aaaaa'") "'original_password' : '***'" >>> mask_password("u'original_password' : u'aaaaa'") "u'original_password' : u'***'" """ message = six.text_type(message) # NOTE(ldbragst): Check to see if anything in message contains any key # specified in _SANITIZE_KEYS, if not then just return the message since # we don't have to mask any passwords. if not any(key in message for key in _SANITIZE_KEYS): return message secret = r'\g<1>' + secret + r'\g<2>' for pattern in _SANITIZE_PATTERNS: message = re.sub(pattern, secret, message) return message
